factoid: Emperor Napoleon had not yet left his bedroom.
Emperor Napoleon was finishing his toilet.
Emperor Napoleon was slightly snorting and grunting.
Emperor Napoleon presented his back to the brush with which Emperor Napoleon's valet was rubbing him down.
Emperor Napoleon presented his plump hairy chest to the brush with which Emperor Napoleon's valet was rubbing him down.
Emperor Napoleon's valet was rubbing him down with a brush.
Another valet had his finger over the mouth of a bottle.
Another valet was sprinkling Eau de Cologne on Emperor Napoleon's body.
Another valet's expression seemed to say that he alone knew where and how much Eau de Cologne should be sprinkled.
Emperor Napoleon's short hair was wet and matted on his forehead.
Emperor Napoleon's face was puffy and yellow.
Emperor Napoleon's face expressed physical satisfaction.
Emperor Napoleon muttered "Go on, harder, go on!" to Emperor Napoleon's valet.
Emperor Napoleon was slightly twitching and grunting.
An aide-de-camp entered the bedroom to report to Emperor Napoleon the number of prisoners taken in yesterday’s action.
The aide-de-camp was standing by the door after delivering his message.
The aide-de-camp was awaiting permission to withdraw.
Emperor Napoleon, frowning, looked at the aide-de-camp from under his brows.
Emperor Napoleon said "No prisoners!" repeating the aide-de-camp’s words.
Emperor Napoleon muttered "They are forcing us to exterminate them. So much the worse for the Russian army.... Go on... harder, harder!".
Emperor Napoleon was hunching his back and presenting his fat shoulders.
Emperor Napoleon said "All right. Let Monsieur de Beausset enter, and Fabvier too."
Emperor Napoleon nodded to the aide-de-camp.
The aide-de-camp said "Yes, sire."
The aide-de-camp disappeared through the door of the tent.
Two valets rapidly dressed Emperor Napoleon.
Emperor Napoleon wore the blue uniform of the Guards.
Emperor Napoleon walked with firm quick steps to the reception room.
De Beausset's hands were busily engaged arranging the present he had brought from the Empress.
The present was on two chairs directly in front of the entrance.
Emperor Napoleon had dressed and come out with unexpected rapidity.
Emperor Napoleon had not time to finish arranging the surprise.
Emperor Napoleon noticed what the valets were about.
Emperor Napoleon guessed that the valets were not ready.
Emperor Napoleon pretended not to see De Beausset.
Emperor Napoleon called Fabvier to him.
Emperor Napoleon listened silently and with a stern frown to what Fabvier told him about the heroism and devotion of his troops fighting at Salamanca.
Emperor Napoleon's troops were fighting at Salamanca at the other end of Europe.
Fabvier told Emperor Napoleon that his troops had one thought—to be worthy of their Emperor.
Fabvier told Emperor Napoleon that his troops had one fear—to fail to please him.
The result of the battle at Salamanca had been deplorable.
Emperor Napoleon made ironic remarks during Fabvier’s account.
Emperor Napoleon did not expect that matters could go otherwise in his absence.
Emperor Napoleon said "I must make up for that in Moscow."
Emperor Napoleon said "I’ll see you later."
Emperor Napoleon summoned De Beausset.
De Beausset had prepared the surprise.
De Beausset had placed something on the chairs.
De Beausset had covered it with a cloth.
De Beausset bowed low.
De Beausset approached Emperor Napoleon.
De Beausset presented an envelope to Emperor Napoleon.
Emperor Napoleon turned to De Beausset gaily.
Emperor Napoleon pulled De Beausset's ear.
Emperor Napoleon said "You have hurried here. I am very glad. Well, what is Paris saying?"
Emperor Napoleon changed his expression from stern to cordial.
De Beausset replied "Sire, all Paris regrets your absence."
Emperor Napoleon knew that De Beausset had to say something of this kind.
Emperor Napoleon knew in his lucid moments that it was untrue.
Emperor Napoleon was pleased to hear it from De Beausset.
Emperor Napoleon honored De Beausset by touching his ear.
Emperor Napoleon said "I am very sorry to have made you travel so far."
De Beausset replied "Sire, I expected nothing less than to find you at the gates of Moscow."
Emperor Napoleon smiled.
Emperor Napoleon lifted his head absent-mindedly.
Emperor Napoleon glanced to the right.
An aide-de-camp approached with gliding steps.
The aide-de-camp offered Emperor Napoleon a gold snuffbox.
Emperor Napoleon took the gold snuffbox.
Emperor Napoleon said "Yes, it has happened luckily for you."
Emperor Napoleon raised the open snuffbox to his nose.
Emperor Napoleon said "You are fond of travel."
Emperor Napoleon said "In three days you will see Moscow."
Emperor Napoleon said "You surely did not expect to see that Asiatic capital."
Emperor Napoleon said "You will have a pleasant journey."
De Beausset bowed gratefully.
De Beausset's taste for travel was not known until then.
Emperor Napoleon asked "Ha, what’s this?"
Emperor Napoleon noticed that all the courtiers were looking at something concealed under a cloth.
De Beausset half turned.
De Beausset did not turn his back to Emperor Napoleon.
De Beausset retired two steps.
De Beausset was twitching off the cloth.
De Beausset said something (content unspecified).
